title: 106_s505
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 1999". The Congress finds that gifted and talented students demonstrate high performance in various areas and require specialized services to fully develop their capabilities. These students come from diverse backgrounds and are often underrepresented in gifted education programs due to their advanced academic abilities. Gifted and talented students have special educational needs that differ from regular education programs. Parents are crucial partners in developing appropriate services for these students. There is no federal requirement to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted students in the nation. Some states and school districts do allocate resources for gifted education. Some states and school districts allocate resources for educating gifted and talented students, but there is a disparity in services due to varying state laws and funding. It is crucial for the United States to ensure that more students achieve higher levels of education to compete in the global economy. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the US on international assessments like TIMSS has been among the lowest in the world. The performance of physics and advanced mathematics students in the United States on international assessments like TIMSS was among the lowest in the world. Elementary school students that are gifted and talented have already mastered a significant portion of the material before the school year begins. In 1990, very little funding was allocated towards providing challenging programming for gifted and talented students in the US. The purpose of this Act is to provide grants to States to support programs for gifted and talented students. The Act provides grants to States for programs and services for gifted and talented students in elementary and secondary schools. The Act authorizes programs and activities for gifted and talented students in elementary and secondary schools. The Secretary can provide grants to States for gifted and talented education programs in public schools. This includes professional development programs, technical assistance, and direct services and materials. States may use funds to provide direct educational services and materials to gifted and talented students, including curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. They can also support innovative approaches and curricula in schools and provide challenging course work to students in schools lacking resources. The funds provided can be used for developing curriculum packages, compensating distance-learning educators, and other relevant purposes. Additionally, not more than 10 percent of the total amount received can be used for State educational agency administrative costs, such as facilitating coordination of gifted education programs, disseminating information to teachers and parents, creating advisory boards, and administering funds. Not more than 2 percent of the total amount received under this Act may be used by a State to provide information, education, and support to parents and caregivers of gifted and talented children to enhance their ability to participate in decisions regarding their children's educational programs. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. The application must assure that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, with a majority going to public schools. Funds should only supplement, not replace, existing state and local funding. The State must ensure that funds supplement, not replace, existing state and local funds for gifted education. The State must also develop program assessment models for accountability. The Secretary will approve a State's application if it meets the requirements. SEC. 5. ALLOTMENT TO STATES. The Secretary will allocate funds to each State based on the number of children aged 5 through 18. Each State meeting the Act's requirements will receive a minimum of $1,000,000 for the fiscal year. If funds are insufficient, allocations will be reduced proportionally. SEC. 6. REPORTING. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the students served and activities supported with funds from the Act, including measures taken to meet accountability requirements. In this Act, "gifted and talented" is defined as per applicable State law or by the State or local educational agency. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. "State" means each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia. "State educational agency" is defined as per section 14101(28) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. Authorization of appropriation of $160,000,000 for fiscal years 2000-2004 to carry out the Act.
